utterances.utterance: This is like the video, where they sent out a doctored video as an official White House document. That's propaganda. That makes people think that the -- what's going on in the White House is really an autocrat.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: If I worked for, let's say, FOX News, and I went into -- into the White House and every day during the press briefing I played mouth trumpet, and it was really, really annoying for everyone in the room, does the White House have a moral obligation to keep me in the room although I'm annoying everyone in there? Going (HUMS THROUGH LIPS)

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They have no obligation to keep you, but they don't have the right to throw you out. Remember, there have been people -- fist fights. This is about protecting the president and his family. That's about it. Other than that, the rest is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So in Juan's opinion, you can go to the White House and you can behave like a total idiot, and they're constitutionally not allowed to touch you. I can still -- next Democrat president, I'm applying for a hard pass. I'm going to misbehave and see how long that lasts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, he can still get a daily pass.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Up next, the PC police outraged over this Serena Williams magazine cover. The controversy up next.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Well, the left is freaking out again, this time over GQ's latest issue honoring tennis star Serena Williams. The magazine cover sparking outrage with some on social media because it features the Woman of the Year title with the word "woman" in quotes. GQ says the move is purely artistic, but others say it's disrespectful to the 23-time Grand Slam champion. The controversial text was apparently handwritten by a fashion designer who uses quotation marks in his designs. Now, Greg, this designer is Virgil Abloh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, of course. Virg.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I do know his stuff, because I like him a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. He does all my socks.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Does he?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Does he put "Greg" in quotes?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He puts me in a lot of things.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: See, he takes the segment just to a terrible place, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here's the deal. Who is outraged? That's the question. Who is the outraged? You can't find the people who are outraged. If you look at the headlines of every story, they go "sparks an outrage." But they don't have -- they don't have the names of the people. Or then they say "causes a backlash." I go and I look them up. They're written by other magazine writers. So what this is, it's a churn. So somebody does this and a person writes about it, and that causes a churn, because they have nothing to write about. They're hopeless writers and editors. It's kind of sad. GQ is not a real magazine anymore.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Virgil does this stuff, Juan, on a lot of his clothes. In fact, he -- he designed this cover. And he designed a tutu for Serena for the U.S. Open where her name, Serena, is also put in quotes. And if you go to the website for his company, Off-White, you will see all sorts of things in quotes. Even the word "website" at the top is in quotation marks. That's part of his branding. But was this a mistake, because when people look at the cover and they don't know the designer and they see "woman" -- is it possible that maybe they assume people might think that it was OK when, in fact, many would be offended, thinking, "Well, is she not a real woman? Are they trying to say something terrible"?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, this is a controversy, actually, that predates. I mean, once she was in the -- I think it was the French Open, somebody made a nasty comment about her body --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and her size and strength. And the lady who wrote Harry Potter--

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: J.K. Rowling.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: J.K. Rowling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: J.K., what is J.K.?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She issued a statement, said she's such a woman and, of course, she just had a baby. She's a woman. But I think there are people who might think that. On the other hand, you know, because I'm a cynic, I'm thinking is this advertising for GQ? Is that what this is?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think, you know, like Greg, I'm not sure.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's like Rolling Stone putting a glamorous shot of one of the Tsarnaev brothers on their magazine. But if you notice, next to the word "woman" in quotes, there's an asterisk. And at the bottom, it says, "Hand writing by Virgil Abloh." So GQ knew that there was going to be a backlash. So --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So you do think that?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: So either they were --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They were doing it on purpose.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Exactly. They knew this was going to happen, and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Stupid magazine.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- they drew even more attention to it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The thing is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Worst magazine ever.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: -- if you look at the cover, though, she looks gorgeous. She looks like a boss. She looks like a powerful, beautiful woman.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's a great, great portrait.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It's amazing to me that so many people ignored that, Jesse, like what a great photo, beautifully designed. She's amazing. She's this amazing talent. And instead, chose to be outraged by something which is clearly defined, as Kennedy said, right in the bottom corner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that a Gucci belt? What is she wearing?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Chanel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Chanel? See, I was close, right? Oh, that's a G.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse is like, "I don't even want to get involved in this. I don't want to get involved."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a minefield for me here.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Fake outrage. You're supposed to comment about fake outrage.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes, very, very outrageous for many people on the left. I mean, you just fill in the blank. "Liberals outraged..." It's like half of our segments.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about the conservative grievance industry? Hmm.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Any last word -- last-minute thoughts.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No. I think -- I love the fact that she owns her strength and power, and she is the GOAT. She's the greatest of all time.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How dare you call her a goat?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I know. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" is coming up.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Even that can be misconstrued.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Mediaite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing," I'll go first. OK, tickets are running out for "The Gutfeld Monologues Live." I've got Tom Shillue opening up. Grand Rapids, Michigan. That's December 2. San Antonio, Texas. That's December 8. They're on the weekend. You can go. For ticket info: GGutfeld.com. They're running up to, like, 80 percent capacity right now. All right. More important --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Is that Joel Gray?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Cat-Off

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Cat-Off." OK, you understand. There are three videos. You're going to watch, and you're going to vote on it. Video one. Here we have a couple of cool cats cruising the streets with friends. You can't get much cooler than a bunch of cats driving around. I find that very inspirational, since I don't have a driver's license. Video two, cat gets a back massage from another cat.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Ohhh!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? If you can't have a feline friend around to make you feel frisky or add a little friction to your life, what good is it? And then finally -- this is the troubling one -- cat's pajamas. They put pajamas on a cat and the cat can't walk around, because the cat is in pajamas. So when they say it's the cat's pajamas, it's obviously a bad thing. All right. Let's go around the table. Jedediah, which video?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: No. 3, cat jammies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cat jammies?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Cat jammies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cat jammies?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I wasn't paying attention to the first one. Was the first one any good?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it was. But I --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go with jammies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on, the first one, because you hope that one of them is Toonces, and they all drive off a cliff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So cat's pajamas win 3-1.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So it's not Thanksgiving yet, but there's Christmas music on my radio. And if you've started your Christmas shopping, you should know that the National Toy Hall of Fame has just announced their class of 2018. The three winners are the magic 8-ball, Uno, the card game, and pinball machines. They will join 65 previous nominees, including such notables as Barbie dolls, Lionel trains, as well as that simple delight, the big cardboard box. Of course, this year's winners seem to be more for people my age than my grandkids. Among the nominees were that ancient vibrating board game, "Electric Football," and the game -- it's a very old game -- Chutes and Ladders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We've got -- I've got a minute 45. I've got to get -- I've got three people. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: My friends at Roback, the best T-shirt company, best golf company, golf shirt company, they did a lot of great stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Freebies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They've raised over $10,000 for American Humane Shelter, the service program which trains and matches rescue dogs with vets suffering from PTSD or traumatic brain injuries. Look at some of the good fans that we have. Jasper is a fan of Roback over here. Who else do we have? John Boehner, big Roback guy. How about the guys over at Barstool Sports with the founders, Kevin and Matt. Party bro Chad Kroger --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We've got to move.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And also "Watters' World," big Roback fan! That's not my boat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Not yet. Guy Fieri, Northern California alum.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great hair.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: He's also a great chef and very charitable, good person. Took a ton of free meals -- pulled pork and plenty of sides -- to all the firefighters --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- who have been working around the clock from many states in order to combat the Camp Fire up north where he was. And of course, the two big fires in Southern California. Thank you, Guy Fieri.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well done. Well done. Great restaurant in Times Square. Jed.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The city of Las Cruces in New Mexico has broken a record, world record: 5,039-pound, 110-foot-long heap of nachos. Look at that deliciousness at Noche de Nachos. Nine hundred pounds of tortilla chips, 450 pounds of salsa, 2,200 pounds of delicious cheese.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do they call cheese that's not yours?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nacho cheese.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nacho cheese.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. We'll end on that. Set your DVRs. Don't laugh at that. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. What's up, Bret?

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS
